PrimEcoSys: Central and Southern Appalachian Northern Hardwood Forest
Central and Southern Appalachian Spruce-Fir Forest

habitat_description: Two subspecies of Northern Flying Squirrel occur in the southern Appalachians: Carolina Northern Flying Squirrel (Glaucomys sabrinus coloratus) and (West) Virginia Northern Flying Squirrel (Glaucomys sabrinus fuscus).  While both have been listed as endangered by the USFWS, only the Carolina Northern Flying Squirrel remains on the list (USFWS 1990).  Both subspecies inhabit high elevation spruce-fir, northern hardwood, and mixed hardwood-hemlock forests (Hughes 2006).  They appear to require a mix of hardwoods and conifers; inhabiting conifer-hardwood ecotones or “mosaics consisting of red spruce (Picea rubens) and fir (Abies fraser and A. balsamea) associated with mature beech (Fagus grandifolia), yellow birch (Betula alleganiensis), sugar maple (Acer saccharum) or red maple (Acer rubrum), hemlock (Tsuga canadensis), and black cherry (Prunus serotina)”(USFWS 1990).  They have been documented in hemlock-hardwood-rhododendron forests (USFWS 1990).  West Virginia captures have been between 1000 – 1350 m; Virginia captures 1170 – 1630 m; and in North Carolina above 1540 m (with the exception of two individuals; USFWS 1990).  N. Tarr, 5March2015.
